head.title: The Tax on the Rich and the Dead

hedline.hl1: The Tax on the Rich and the Dead

abstract.p: Patrick J A McClain letter on Mar 22 Op-Ed article comments on right of individuals to distribute their wealth as they see fit

block.p: Michael S. McPherson and Morton Owen Schapiro (''A Sensible Tax on Fortunes,'' Op-Ed, March 22) acknowledge that those who accumulate wealth have ''at least a limited moral right to distribute it as they wish.'' They then go on to propose a system of taxation that would result in such distributions largely ending up in the hands of government.

Michael S. McPherson and Morton Owen Schapiro (''A Sensible Tax on Fortunes,'' Op-Ed, March 22) acknowledge that those who accumulate wealth have ''at least a limited moral right to distribute it as they wish.'' They then go on to propose a system of taxation that would result in such distributions largely ending up in the hands of government.

Their idea seems to be that as long as the tax is nominally levied on the recipient rather than the giver, the moral problem is avoided. I fail to see how the right of an individual to distribute her wealth as she sees fit is being respected if the intended recipient doesn't actually receive the gift.
PATRICK J. A. MCCLAIN Herndon, Va., March 22, 2001
